awd_titl_txt: Chiral Spin Textures in Magnetic Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Magnetic moments in magnets can form various configurations known as spin textures, such as domain walls where the moments form a winding configuration connecting adjacent domains with different magnetization directions. Usually, the rotational sense of the moments in spin textures is expected to be achiral, where the left- and right-handed rotations are equally possible. In certain magnetic thin films, the broken inversion symmetry of atomic structure at the interface between magnetic and heavy metal layers leads to an interfacial effect which lifts the chiral degeneracy and stabilizes chiral spin structures such as spin spirals, chiral domain walls or magnetic skyrmions. These chiral spin textures exhibit a preferred handedness and fascinating topological characteristics. Their extraordinary properties provide new insights into fundamental problems of magnetism and exciting potentials for novel magnetic technologies.  This project aims at significantly advancing the field by unlocking a number of degrees of freedom for a better understanding and control of such spin textures. Several novel spin textures are investigated, including exotic types of skyrmions and chiral domain walls in 2-dimensional thin films and topological spin textures such as Mobius bands in 3-dimensional magnetic structures. They have the potential to fundamentally transform the energy landscape for future information storage. This project provides valuable training opportunities for students in university as well as national laboratory and other facilities. The principal investigator actively engages in a variety of efforts to broaden participation from underrepresented groups through course offering, public lectures, exchange visits, and professional conference organization.

Technical Abstract:
Chiral spin textures are investigated to demonstrate a number of new degrees of freedom to better control them, including antiskyrmion Hall angle, topological number, chemisorbed species, and 3-dimensional topological configuration. Anisotropic Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction is utilized to stabilize antiskyrmions in magnetic thin films. The antiskyrmion Hall angle is explored for controlling skyrmion trajectory or topological sorting, which can be potentially used for designing complex skyrmionics devices. High winding number skyrmions are demonstrated, which unlocks the topological number as a new degree of freedom that may support novel topological functionalities in logic devices. Effects of chemisorbed species under vacuum onto ferromagnet films are studied to induce chiral domain walls and enable direct writing of skyrmions without magnetic or electric fields. Chemisorptions of low atomic number atoms and organic molecules are studied to induce reversible switching of magnetic chirality and tuning of perpendicular magnetic anisotropy. Novel types of 3-dimensional topological spin textures such as Mobius bands are fabricated and their topological characters are investigated. These novel spin textures offer new mechanisms for robust and low dissipation information storage, which is well aligned with grand challenges for future nanoelectronics. This project includes a wide variety of efforts to broaden participation from underrepresented groups. Students involved receive excellent exposure to research experience in academia, government laboratory and other research facilities.

This DMR grant supports research on chiral spin structure in magnetic nanoparticles with funding from the Condensed Matter Physics (CMP) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) Programs in the Division of Materials Research of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nanoscale magnets are widely used for information storage and increasingly find more applications in nanoelectronics because they are efficient information carriers. Usually in nanoscale magnetic configurations known as spin textures, such as magnetic domain walls, the right- and left-handed spin rotations are energetically equivalent. Under certain circumstances, the adjacent spins in the materials form certain preferred winding configurations that possess topological characters, such as magnetic skyrmions and chiral domain walls. These novel spin textures are the focus of this project, as they provide new insights into fundamental problems of magnetism and exciting potentials for novel magnetic technologies. 

 

Intellectual Merit         

In thin film systems, the chiral spin texture arises from an antisymmetric exchange interaction between adjacent spins known as the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction, or DMI. The interfacial DMI is usually found in magnetic layers next to heavy metals due to the strong spin-orbit coupling. Using spin polarized low-energy electron microscopy (SPLEEM), we have discovered a hydrogen-induced DMI at the surface of certain ferromagnets at room temperature, and a reversible control of the magnetic chirality and spin textures. The physical origin of the induced DMI is the change in the spatial asymmetry of the wave function in the transition metals, induced by a small charge transfer. Furthermore, the hydrogen adsorption can change the balance of magnetic energy contributions, particularly reducing the perpendicular magnetic anisotropy, which can be used to reversibly write and delete magnetic skyrmions. Such ambient temperature skyrmion operations in the absence of magnetic field, gate voltage or electric current provide new paths for the design of skyrmion-based spintronics and magneto-ionic devices.

Furthermore, we have observed an extremely sensitive and complete switching of the DMI and domain wall chirality induced by a sub-monolayer Pd capping layer. When the strength of the DMI is tuned to cross the 0-DMI point, the topology of this skyrmion is no longer protected.  The minimum DMI energy barrier for the chirality switching of a skyrmion is estimated to be at the sub-attojoule level for a micron-sized skyrmion, which is highly attractive for energy-efficient skyrmionics devices. 

We have investigated magneto-ionic means to achieve high-quality MnNx thin films which may host topological spin textures. By sputtering Mn onto Mn3N2 seed layers on Si substrates, nitrogen ion migration across the Mn3N2/Mn layers leads to a continuous evolution of the layers to form a variety of MnNx phases, as well as a significant exchange bias. These results demonstrate a promising all-nitride magneto-ionic platform with remarkable tunability.

Additionally, we have explored 2-dimensional van der Waals (vdW) ferromagnets. Materials that can host multiple skyrmion phases are particularly interesting as they provide a new degree of freedom in designing spintronic devices. In collaboration with Jagadeesh Moodera’s group at MIT and Gen Yin at Georgetown, we have investigated vdW heterostructures and confirmed that they can host two groups of magnetic skyrmions using micromagnetic simulations. The spin textures and the corresponding topological charge density profiles during the field scan demonstrate the evolution of stripe domains and magnetic skyrmions.

Another area we have explored is the correlation of macroscopic magnetometry measurement with quantitative, microscopic properties of hysteretic systems using the first-order reversal curve (FORC) method. Using magnetic transmission X-ray microscopy, we have carried out local element-specific FORC measurements on CoTb films, which reveal the domain evolution under the magnetic field cycling. They show quantitative agreement with magnetometry based FORCs, providing a direct visualization of the reversal mechanisms, and demonstrating the confluence of two powerful techniques to achieve quantitative insights.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has potentially important technological impacts. For example, our results on chemisorption induced DMI and magnetic anisotropy represent a significant advancement in chiral spintronics using chemisorption as a handle to introduce topology into real space configurations of spin textures. These findings together offer a tunable and contactless way to tailor spin textures through DMI or anisotropy, after the materials stack have been made, enabling adaptive capabilities. They have important implications in magnetic memory and logic devices, particularly for the envisioned 3D information storage, as well as solid state magneto-ionic devices. The sub-attojoule energy cost associated with skyrmion chirality switching near the zero DMI point is attractive for energy-efficient skyrmionics devices. The studies on 2D vdW heterostructures demonstrates a platform for hosting two groups of magnetic skyrmions. By proper design of multilayer 2D magnetic stack, different groups of skyrmions can be formed vertically, adding a new degree of freedom to skyrmion-based spintronic devices.

This project has provided partial support to 3 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral fellows. Two of the students graduated with Ph.D. degrees in 2023, and one received a prestigious Fellowship from the National Research Council Research Associateship Programs. The results have been disseminated in over 20 refereed journal publications so far, several submitted manuscripts, 2 patent applications, and over 50 invited talks at conferences and research institutes, including many at major conferences.
